posts.post_content: As mentioned in a recent article on wizards.com, the double Sharuum does indeed work. Because both creatures die when state based effects are checked they are put into the graveyard even before their abilities go onto the stack. Thus, when the abilities are put onto the stack you select a target (one of the Sharuums) bringing it back. Rinse repeat.
posts.html:
As mentioned in a recent article on wizards.com, the double Sharuum does indeed work. Because both creatures die when state based effects are checked they are put into the graveyard even before their abilities go onto the stack. Thus, when the abilities are put onto the stack you select a target (one of the Sharuums) bringing it back. Rinse repeat.

Posted By: duoclops (6/10/2009 10:18:22 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: Sharuum is a very awesome card, being a beefy flier as well as having an awesome graveyard-to-play ability which can target any number of irritating artifacts that may have recently been put into the graveyard ([Scourgl\*\*\*](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Scourgl***), anyone?). Her price is also something to be giddy about, as you should essentially get 2 very good artifacts for the price of one, making Sharuum very efficient and sneaky in any artifact based deck. And yes, Sharuum is a "her;" Note the "She" in her flavor text as well as certain tell-tale anatomical structures in her art.
posts.html:
Sharuum is a very awesome card, being a beefy flier as well as having an awesome graveyard-to-play ability which can target any number of irritating artifacts that may have recently been put into the graveyard (Scourgl***, anyone?). Her price is also something to be giddy about, as you should essentially get 2 very good artifacts for the price of one, making Sharuum very efficient and sneaky in any artifact based deck. And yes, Sharuum is a "her;" Note the "She" in her flavor text as well as certain tell-tale anatomical structures in her art.

Posted By: Oleander (3/2/2009 11:05:07 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
There are some wicked combos out there that no one has mentioned thus far.  
[Master Transmuter](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Master Transmuter) can drop him for 1, and if you already have a Sharuum in the graveyard, you can bring him back. This would mean they both get sent to the graveyard, but since the Sharuum did hit the field, his ability still has to resolve, so you can target the Sharuum in your graveyard bringing him back, which in turn brings your other Sharuum back, and there we have an infinite loop.  
I haven't done too much research into this, but i believe there are some cards that can use this leaving play/entering play effect, such as [Sludge Strider](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sludge Strider). Every time the Sharuum effect happens, you can pay 4 and gain 4 life with your opponent losing 4.  
Having a [Gl\*\*\*dust Hulk](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Gl***dust Hulk) on the field before starting the Sharuum combo would mean its power and toughness are infinite, and it is unblockable. Similar effect with [Glaze Fiend](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Glaze Fiend)  
Godtracker ... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

posts.post_content: yes duoclops is right. state based effects, such as multiple of a legendary, are checked whenever a player would receive priority, which is also when a triggered ability will be put on the stack, so both sharuums will be in the graveyard when the ability goes on the stack, great with gl\*\*\*dust hulk/glaze fiend =).
